abstract.p: Dr Jill Strasser letter on July 18 article cite importance of Prozac and other antidepressant drugs for people who suffer from major depressive disorders; photo

block.p: Re ''Once Again, Prozac Takes Center Stage, in Furor'' (July 18): As a psychologist, I agree that Prozac and other antidepressants are often overemphasized by insurance companies seeking ways to shorten psychological treatment.

Re ''Once Again, Prozac Takes Center Stage, in Furor'' (July 18): As a psychologist, I agree that Prozac and other antidepressants are often overemphasized by insurance companies seeking ways to shorten psychological treatment.

I also agree that these medications may be overprescribed for complaints that are societal, not biological. My concern is for people who suffer from major depressive disorders and for whom all the talk therapy in the world will not alleviate their suffering. People who suffer from depression are already beset by shame and many are reluctant to take medication.

For these people, medications like Prozac offer a way out of the hopelessness, helplessness and despair that is depression. We don't know about the long-term effects of these drugs but we do know about the long-term effects of depression, a chronic, debilitating and, at times, life-threatening disorder.
Until we have more solid proof that the cure is worse than the disease, I will urge my patients for whom these medications seem appropriate to take them as directed.
